It's because of FIFO.
The First photon hits the mirror and turns back to our eyes, and then the next after that. Imagine an array of photons bouncing off of you towards the mirror. Turning around and facing yourself is not a horizontal flip. Its a horizontal rotation.
If you have a transform for turning around, it would look like this:
loc: <0.0, 0.0, 0.0>
rot: <0.0, 90.0, 0.0>
scale: <1.0, 1.0, 1.0>

But a transform for what you look like in a mirror would be:
loc: <0.0, 0.0, 0.0>
rot: <0.0, 0.0, 0.0>
scale: <1.0, 1.0, -1.0>

and these do not result in the same thing as you pointed out with the glove
the hand to your right when you look in a mirror is still your right hand but if you could turn around and
face yourself, the hand to your right would be your left.

Since you can equate what you look like turning around and facing yourself to how other people see you,
this also means that the way you see yourself in the mirror is not how other people see you.

I learned in Grade  7 that light rays from an object fall into a mirror laterally inverted as opposed to the rays passing through a convex lens where they get vertically inverted.   Therefore, the reflected images in a mirror appears laterally inverted (left appears as right and right as left) whereas the photographic image formed through the lens appears upside down or vertically inverted. These were simple lab experiments for us in those days.  I don’t think the basics have changed.

The mirror doesn't have a direction for "flipping" the image. The "flip" is purely imagined. I'll explain:

Light leaves you. It bounces off the mirror. It returns to you, to your eyes.
Light from your top returns from the top.
Light from your bottom returns from the bottom.
Light from your right returns from the right.
Light from your left returns from the left.

Nothing is "flipped."
So, where's" the flipping?
It's in our imagination.
We imagine that all this light returning to us is a person before us, another "me" that is beyond the glass in a mirror universe.
In imagining so, we imagine putting our soul, our conscious being, into the mirror self. But how?
The fact is, you cannot. If your conscious being were to somehow project into the mirror self, it wouldn't fit. This is something in physics or math called "chirality" or "handedness".
The imagined mirror self has the opposite chirality. Everything there is opposite. The DNA molecules use the opposite shaped molecules and spin the opposite way. Different nutrients are the opposite of what they are in our space.

We try to use our imagination to fit our conscious self into the mirror self:

Attempt 1) project straight in:
Up is still up. Down is still down.
Right is still right. Left is still left.
But front is now back, and back is front.
Not good.

Attempt 2) flip top to bottom as you go in:
Right is right. Left is left.
Front is front. Back is back.
But, now top is bottom and bottom is top.
Really not good.

Attempt 3) spin left to right as I enter:
Front is front. Back is back.
Up is up. Down is down.
But left is right, right is left.
In our mind, this result is ok. Things fit pretty well.
My hand is where my hand should be. Sure my conscious hand is in the wrong hand, but it's pretty good.
Sure, my stomach is going the wrong way.
Sure, my spleen is on the wrong side.
But all said, this imagined attempt of my conscious self occupying the mirror self is a fit I'm most comfortable with.

And that's it.
The mirror didn't flip anything. Our imagination perceiving what we see as a self in mirror world causes us to imagine flipping our being left to right to fit into the mirror self.
And why, because of the three ways to flip, flipping left to right our bodies are reasonably symmetrical. Thus we're mentally ok with that flip.

If there existed an alien who was asymmetrical left to right, and top to bottom, but they were symmetrical back to front, they would be asking "Why do mirrors flip back to front and not right to left or top to bottom?"

Test this:
Hold a spatula in front of a mirror. How is it "flipped?"
You'll see, it depends on how you hold the spatula.
The spatula, like us, is symmetrical in only 1 of the three dimensions.
If you hold it so the symmetrical sides are left to right, you perceive a right left flip.
If you turn the spatula so that the symmetry is too to bottom, you perceive it's flipped top to bottom in the mirror.
And if you hold it so that the symmetry is back to front, you perceive that flip.

Okay, you're going to say that normal viewing flips how we see backwards. But then you also have to take into account how our eyes flip the light coming in vertically. Our brains re-flip what we think we see into its actual position so that we can interact with reality. So, I think our brains don't manage a "consistency" flip when we look in a mirror, but we have to consciously do that ourselves.

That's why dogs don't recognize themselves in a mirror. You see "doof" in the mirror and you think to read "food." But a dog doesn't do that. What the dog with a steak sees in the mirror is another dog with another steak on the other side of the room, separated by some weird force field that neither can cross.

Mirrors don't exist in nature. Seeing yourself in a still pool is like seeing a rainbow. The colors are not in the sky, but it's the refraction of the light. And neither is the "other dog" on the other side of the mirror, but the dog doesn't understand "reflection."

And maybe I don't either. It's some kind of weird paradox created by having to consciously flip the image, but not being able to flip how we see it. 🤔 The primary way that I recognize that I'm seeing a "reflection" (if I'm not looking at my own familiar face) is by seeing the mimicry of the motion. I'm sorry, but that doesn't make sense (the video title, that is).
They don't "flip" anything, horizontally or vertically. They simply reflect the visible signal from objects in a return path at an equal angle to the observer's vision.
It doesn't matter whether it's up, down, left, or right.

If the part of the image you see is coming from below, you see a reflection somewhere along mid-heigth of the reflective surface. From above, same thing. From the sides, this translates to the same concept, with the only difference being that the point of emmision is lateral.
The entire image is thus observed at the point where your eyes are.
Nothing is flipped, it's just reversed. Up and down are still up and down.

You'll get the same result if the reflective surface is above or below you, but our spatial orientation interprets the image as being upside-down in relation to our actual orientation while standing on this planet, which we have evolved to interact with through millions of years. If we weren't wired that way, we would hardly notice, any more than we adapt to a reversed image when shaving or putting on makeup. We know we need to move in relation to our actual position, but we quickly learn to respond to what we see in the mirror with opposing movements.

I don't think it's about what the mirror does, but how we interpret the image -- due to the fact that we are horizontally symmetrical. If we lived on our sides (with all of our writing, screens, etc. rotated by 90 degrees) we would interpret the world differently. So, if lying on, say, our left side when looking in the mirror, we would see the exactly the same mirror image as we do now, but our right side would be "up" (and left side "down") -- so we would interpret that as a mirror image with a vertical flip. (Also, if wearing a tee-shirt with FOOD on it, whilst lying down, sideways, then the mirror image of the word would be flipped -- vertically.) The mirror has no horizontal or vertical preference!

The question that the whole video is based on is incorrect. Mirrors don't "flip" anything in any direction. If you lay down in front of a mirror are your feet on the other side- horizontally?

Mirrors reflect points of light over their planar surface. The angle of incidents for these points of light is equal to the angle of reflection. It's like a pool ball bouncing off of the edge of the table - only in more dimensions. When you see a point of light from the very edge of your right ear, it reflects to your eye from a spot between your eye and edge of your ear. Same for your chin, left ear, top of your head, words on your shirt etc. No flipping, just reflecting.

Now, take a pin hole camera and you get upside-down and backwards. But that's because the light is passing through a point rather than reflecting off of a plane.

It is our species' specific type of body symmetry which makes the determination.
We compare the reflection to our real body by imagining ourselves going around behind the mirror, and comparing our real body with the reflection. How can we get behind the mirror? We can (1) imagine slithering over the top of it and descending head first, to compare our body to the reflection, or (2) we can imagine walking around behind the mirror and standing beside our reflection.
In #1 left and right coincide while top and bottom are reversed.
In #2 up and down are preserved while left and right exchange places.
Because of our sagittal symmetry we choose method #2.

This is how I understand it.
Our sense of left and right are special, if you look to your left you see your left hand, (write an L on that hand), look to the right you see your right hand ( mark an R on that hand). 
But imagine if eyes were transplanted onto the back of your head, now when you look to your left you see your right hand, with the R, and when you look to the right you see your left hand, with the L.
There is no change to what you feel is up and down.
The transplanting of your eyes onto the back of your head is what the mirror does, but it transplants everything on your body to point backwards (we tend to look better that way).
But mirror has no effect on up and down, as these directions are independent of whether or not our body has had a front to back reversal.

A mirror does not swap left and right but instead swaps front and back, which only to us as a swap of left and right, but has no affect on up and down.

Have you considere distorting (warping) mirrors? Much more fun than "standard" plane mirrors. They make you thinner, fatter or with a disproportionally big or small head, etc. (appart from possibly also invert chiriality (parity in physics) ). Oh, and they could also show you upside-down. The fun is not in the images produced (not only), but to think in what we do (unconciously) to compare spatial shapes and express the difference in the most simple/intuitive way. First, we know (intuitively) that movement in space (a combinación of translations and rotations) do not alter shapes. Then our brain mentally move the shapes to be compared to make them coincide, or be as close to coincide as possible (for our intuition) , and then we see what other (not movement) transformations are necessary to complete the coincidente (like enlargements/shrinkings in different directions, inversiones, simmetries about a plane, etc.). If the objects are complex, they can be divide in parts (head, feets, etc.). In simple cases, like plane standard mirrors images, almost everybody does the same, in complex cases our "automátic" intuitive algorithm could not work or be different for different people.
Then we say what is the relationship among shapes according to the transformations after the movement.
In the simple mirror case, reflecting a person, the movement that makes the shapes (original vs imaginary reflected object) to be the closest to coincide, make the planes of bilateral symmetry of human body to coincide, then, the remainder transformation to make the shapes to totally coincide is a symmetry invertíng left and right, and that is finally what reach es our concioussness: mirrors invert left and right.
All this to show what incredíble a Mount of calculations and algorithms our brain apply automatically and then it pases just a "conclusión" to our conciousness, that have no idea of the procesos, and that only can grasp with difficulty a colarse idea of
Wich was the process.

I watched 30 seconds of this  mirror video and the only thing I do not understand is how people do not understand what is happening when you are looking into a mirror.  The mirror is not flipping anything around. This may be your perception but it is not what is happening.  The mirror is only reflecting back what is directly in front of each spot on the mirror. Think of the surface of the mirror as being made up of pixels like a video screen, each 'pixel' only reflecting back what is directly in front of it.  So, the pixels opposite your hand reflect back your hand in the exact way it "sees" it. Same for the 'pixels' opposite your shoulders or your head.  Nothing is being reversed, it only appears that way.  The 'pixels' opposite your head can only reflect back what it sees, that being your head.  It is simply a piece of glass and is in no way capable of putting another image there such as your feet or whatever.

I think I just thought of an easy way to explain what mirrors do to text: write some text on see-through paper; turn the paper away from you (horizontally) and hold it up to a light. You should see the text flipped as in a mirror. The mirror isn't flipping the text. You are. It's just that you can't see that the text is flipped (from your perspective) without the aid of a mirror. It's all about perspective. Mirrors give us a perspective that we aren't normally able to see.
Another way to think of it is that the text looks inverted because the mirror isn't flipping it. You see, in order for flipped text to appear normal there must also be a corresponding flip in perspective. So if you flip a paper with text on it to show someone, the person sees the text as normal because their perspective is also flipped in relation to your own. But the mirror exactly mirrors what is presented to it without flipping the perspective. So if you flip text to the mirror the mirror exactly mirrors the flipped text.

Mirrors reflect the light exactly as it hits it- in other words, if you touch the mirror with your right hand, left hand, right foot, left foot, and your head, you'll easily see that every single body part touches the mirror together.

In other words, your head won't be touching your mirror's thighs. Instead, your head touches mirror head- your feet touch mirror feet, your hands touch mirror hands. That's how the light hits it. If you want to invert your reflection, you have to concave the mirror. This is basic mirrorness.

Great video, especially the part with the arrows showing the Z-axis switch! Nevertheless, perhaps the question should really be: Why does a mirror flip LEFT and RIGHT, but does not flip UP and DOWN?
And the answer is that UP and DOWN have "absolute" definitions -- towards (or away from) an external entity -- the ground.
In contrast, LEFT and RIGHT have "relative" definitions -- specifically relative to the direction in which one is looking. RIGHT is the direction in which one is looking rotated +90% horizontally, while LEFT is the direction in which one is looking rotated -90% horizontally.
Since the mirror flips the direction in which one is looking, this automatically flips LEFT and RIGHT as well.

If LEFT and RIGHT were defined in "absolute" terms, e.g. "towards the door", then they would not have been swapped by the mirror either.

So it comes down to the combination of the relative term definitions and the flip of the direction one is looking in.

This is more of a psychological trap than anything, but yes, a z-flip is the best way to mathematically describe what a reflection would be if it were an actual world behind the mirror. In reality, what you're seeing is closer to what you'd get by tracing your hand shape onto a piece of paper, or making a hand print using finger paint, just with far more visual detail. It's those details that trip us up and lead us to ascribing more meaning than necessary.

Thank you for your explanation! This question has baffled me for some time, and I never found an satisfying explanation before watching this. The most satisfying one I'd seen beforehand came from Martin Gardner, who imagined that we live in a world of live T-pots, whose mirror images are top-T's. Gardner makes the point that to a T-pot, his mirror image would not appear to be vertically flipped, but instead converted into a top-T, which doesn't exist in his T-pot world. I think this explanation is related to the fact that we have bilateral symmetry, so that we incorrectly interpret the mirror's z-axis flip as an x-axis flip.

The key point here is "rotate on Z axis".
You stand straight before the mirror, your left hand is now on the right side in mirror and vice versa. It flipped horizontally.
Rotate 90 degree (either on right or left) around your pen*s (yes, it's the Z axis). Now your left hand is upside/downside, but in the mirror your left hand is downside/upside. It flipped vertically.

It is because our perception of left and right follows our perception of front and behind, and our perception of up and bottom. Our front is tied to our face, our up is tied to our head. If you put a mirror in front of you, the mirror actually reverses your front and behind, but because our perception of left and right follows our perception of front and behind, the left and right are reversed. If you put a mirror beside you, the left and right are reversed. Now if you put a mirror below you, the up and bottom are reversed but since our left and right follows our up and bottom, the left and right are also reversed.

To be more objective, use cardinal direction (N, W, S, E) instead of left and right. Head North as your front, and your bottom is the earth core and your up is the sky. Hold something at your left hand and put a mirror in front of you. Your face is now in the South and your left hand is still in the West because the mirror only reverses North and South if you place it in front of you. Place it beside you and now your left hand is in the East because the mirror only reverses West and East. Place the mirror below you, now your head is at the bottom, towards the earth core and your left hand is still in the West because the mirror only reverses up and bottom.

If you are facing a mirror on the wall in front of you, what changes is the distance to things. Left is still left, right is still right, up is still up, and down is still down. But, things furthest from you now are closest in the reflection. Instead of using words, just use solid-colored blocks. Then it is obvious.
Now, if you put the mirror on the floor, then what you see of the reflection of what is on the wall is still: left is left, right is right, near is near and far is far; but up is now down and down is now up.
If the mirror is on the wall to your side, then what you see of the reflection of the wall in front of you is still: near is near, far is far, up is up and down is down; but left is now right and right is now left.
It is the coordinate of in the direction of the perpendicular to the mirror which flips.

Using two Flat Mirrors, together, you can create an overall single mirror that will horizontally reverse your image (when compared to what an ordinary Mirror would do.) For simplicity, go to the corner of a room, and, while there, attach one Flat Mirror to the wall on the right, and the other Flat Mirror to the wall on the left. Now, with each mirror individually, slide the mirror until its nearest edge is touching the actual corner of the room. At this point, the two mirrors should be oriented so that, together, they form a 90-degree angle. When you stand in front of this arrangement, you should notice that this "combo" Mirror produces an image that reverses images on the horizontal . You will probably also notice that, if you stare with only one eye open, the center of your pupil will always fall on the Straight Line where the two mirrors meet, even as you move slightly Left or slightly Right.

When we think of mirroring something, we only think of mirroring it on 1 axis because I'm 3 dimensions, it's the only possible way to mirror something.

First off you can only mirror once per axis, because mirroring twice would get you back where you started. Any odd number of mirroring is the same as mirroring once and any even number is not mirrored at all.

So looking at our options for 3d space:
Mirror only one of any of the 3 and the result can be translated by rotating 180° on the axis tangent using right hand rule and arrive at the same mirrored world that you'd get mirroring and translating on another axis.

But mirroring 2 of the three dimensions is the fun part. Because the same rule for mirroring multiple times on the same axis applies for mirroring once on more than 1 axis. Mirror x = mirrored world, then mirror y = normal world.

The reason this happens is because all mirrored axis produce the same result in 3D space. So mirroring all 3 axis results in the same mirrored world from mirroring 1 axis.

There is only 1 way to mirror things in 3D space assuming you translate the cotangent axis normative to the non-mirrored world by rotating 180° on the tangent axis.

In 1 dimension, there's no such thing as mirroring... It's an arbitrary positive negative swap, you don't have a tangent axis to show any difference in 1D topography.

This next part is my own speculation based on my existing understanding. So don't take this next part as certain just an interesting thought experiment. In (maybe 4 I'm not sure), 5, 7 and every odd number Dimensional space, my understanding would lead me to believe you can simultaneously mirror in n-3 unique ways where n is the number of dimensions. It's hard to imagine. But if you left and right is swapped and nothing else is, imagine a separate 2D space being able to be mirrored or not mirrored as well. that's just the 2 cases we could understand if we lived in a 5d universe but couldn't perceive or move through 2 of the dimensions. But all other ways that universe could be mirrored are incomprehensible to our 3D intuitive brains. Whether or not you could rotate any of these in 5D space to result in the same mirroing is beyond me and I haven't studied the math on it. But at least (n-3) is my guess.

In 3D programming you can achieve a reflection render by projecting the viewpoint through the plane of the mirror, and rendering the scene with that. The viewpoint is made up of a position and a left, up and forward vector representing the orientation. When standing in front of a mirror looking at it, the reflected viewpoint has a new position and forward vector, but the left and up vector remain the same. When looking along the forward vector of this new viewpoint, the left vector is now pointing to the right, but the up vector is still the same. The effect is to flip things horizontally but not vertically. So, math supports it too!

It's all about a subjective view. We keep our left hand on our left side, but if we stand in front of another person our left hand on our left side is on the right side of the person in front of us. If we flip vertically, up and down will not flip with us, because up and down are not subjective. Same thing with east and west, north and south. Consider annother thing. A mirror reflects light. Everything shown by a mirror reflects in a straight line something in front of the mirror, every point on the mirror is connected to a point in the real world by a straight. The only two lines perpendicular to the mirror are those, starting from the center of our pupils, looking at the mirror (we see it as one point between our eyes, because of our stereoscopic view), if we stand in front of the mirror and look directly into our eyes. Every straight line is converging to a vanishing point, which would be far behind the mirror, if the image would be fix like a picture. Actually those straight lines meet on the mirror, as the picture we see changes when we turn our head. So the vanishing point is right on the surface on the mirror between the the straight lines starting from our pupils. Those lines will never cross, not one single time. And this is actually the reason we se up where's up and left where's left. You do not believe me? Try to take a look at your image shown by the concave side of a spoon. Go to a mirror and hold up your hands, palms facing the mirror. Your right hand appears to be on the left side of your body in the mirror and the left hand on the right side of your body in the mirror. And yet, two different letters written on each hand stay on the same sides...what?


You are probably imagining a mirror image like a copy of yourself walked behind the glass and turned 180 degrees to face you. Now his/her left hand should be opposite your right hand, and vice versa. But this is not what is happening. The reflection didn't do a 180 degree turn. It was reversed front to back with no rotation at all, along the z axis.


By "turning yourself inside out", here is how I visualize it...Moving the body parts ONLY in the Z direction (forward and backward) imagine your front body parts, including your palms displayed forward, sinking through your body and coming out like that glove turned inside out on the other side (so your nose and stuff is still sticking out rather than in)


If your face suddenly moved to the back of your head, and the backs of your hands became your palms, etc (a reversal in the z direction)...the hand that was formerly your right would become your left...


The flipping of the written letters on each hand in the left-right plane is like she said...just because WE turned our hands.

I have an idea you might like. Can you please do a video on a common misconception about vision. The eye is said to operate like a camera, flipping the image of the outside world upside down 🙃 onto the back of the retina. Common folklore says that the brain "somehow" flips the image back over so that we can see right side up. Fact of the matter is, the brain does not have to flip anything over ; the 180 degree flip is a correct image of the outside world and the brain simply correlates its sensory inputs from touch, sound, and muscular movement, with the  images on its retinas. The brain cannot have any idea that it is seeing the world upside down. In fact no animal's brain equipped with convex lenses can know it is seeing the world upside down. As far as the brain is concerned, from the very first moment its eyes see first light from the outside world at birth, it is seeing a right side up image, and it uses its other senses in concert with sight to orient itself. You can prove this to yourself with spherical water drop (or any lens shaped piece of glass) that flips the image in front of it upside down - Your eye is like that lens, but your brain can only see what is on that lens. If you move the lens left, up, down, or right, the brain still sees exactly what is in front of its eyes; No need for the brain to reprocess the image and flip it back over. If your head turns left to look at a sound or something coming from its left, say a train with its horn blaring, the brain will observe that  the sensation of its neck muscles turning its head left and the sound from the train entering more loudly into its left ear, will be synchronized with the image of the train it is capturing through its eyes - It can never know it is seeing the world upside down. We are fortunate that the laws of physics have determined that lenses flip light rays over 180 degrees.

As Dianna explains, mirrors seemingly do the equivalent of flipping depth, or front to back (what she calls “Z axis").To understand this better look at a 3 second scene from the film Terminator-2: Judgement Day ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8h8d2XLWKY ). The scene takes place at one minute and 12 seconds when the old terminator model, T-800 (played by actor Arnold Schwarzenegger) slams the new terminator model T-1000 (played by actor Robert Patrick) against a wall. ​In this scene, the T-1000 terminator (which is made up of a “mimetic metal polyalloy”) flips itself front to back. His left hand becomes his right hand and vice versa, but his left hand is not flipped horizontally in the opposite direction to occupy the position previously occupied by his right hand. Mirrors do the equivalent of the effect portrayed in this scene.

In short: mirror flips on the axis perpendicular to the mirror. Let's call it Z axis. But flipping on Z axis produces exactly the same movement as rotating around vertical axis (Y axis) on 180° and then flipping on X axis (from left to right) -- check it yourself!
Flip_Z = Rot_Y • Flip_X
We don't care about rotation, hence the illusion. But if mirrors flipped only on X axis, our images would stand with his back to us!

I think this video still missed the key point.
The key is how we define these directions.
Left, right, forward, backward, up, and down, they are all relative directions, but they are usually defined differently
We tend to define forward, backward, up, and down first base on how the object looks, then we decide their left and right base on those 4 predefined directions.
We define where people are facing as forward, where their head pointing as up and legs pointing down(Or possibly the direction to the earth as down, and away from the earth as up). Then base on those 4 directions, you decide which is their left and which is their right.
So, when you say you are putting your hand up, base on how you define "up", you are either putting your hand away from the earth or putting it away from your feet(not necessarily the same direction, e.g. when you are lying on the floor).
The mirror did flip you, but now you are redefining up as where your mirrored self's head is pointing, and forward as where they're facing. So of course, they are still putting their hands up as you do, because that's how their "up" is defined.
If we define left and right before defining up and down, the mirror will flip up and down instead of left and right. For example, if you raise your right hand before the mirror, and you define the raised hand side as right and the not raised hand side as left. And of course where the face facing is forward. You will find your mirrored self upside down by definition.

You explain how a mirror really works (flipping the image back to front), but this doesn't explain why it appears that left and right is flipped.
For this you have to understand that flipping back to front (this is what the mirror does) is the same as the composition of:
1. rotating 180° around the up-down axis (this is what your head does, you basically walk behind the mirror in your head)
2. flipping left and right (this is what is looks like after your head has already done the rotating in step 1)

And this only is the case with mirrors on the wall, if the mirror is on the ground (like a lake) you don't get the same kind of confusion. The Mountain top behind a lake gets flipped to the bottom just like it should be. Our head does no additional rotating in this case.

It's bouncing light. Light flips when it is channelled through an aperture like our eyes but, a camera or a hole in a sheet. But a Mirror isn't an aperture it is reflecting not channelling.

When like travels through an aperture it hits the sides of the aperture and bounces like like it does with a mirror but an Aperture has many sides. So the light from the top bounces up but the edge of absorbs most of it and so the light travelling through from lower angle passes through the aperture and drowns out any reflected light, while the walls around the aperture blocks all light travelling straight, except the bit that is the size of the aperture. The rest of the aperture prevents extra light from travelling through. >|< Light travelling down from the top on one side keeps travelling down appearing at the bottom and the light travelling up from one side ends up at the top of the other. If you have a surface at the right distance from the aperture you'll actually see all the image upside down but only if there is no light to wash it out.

A mirror doesn't have an aperture to block or absorb enough bounced light. So ALL the light is reflected off it at the same strength or less depending on how reflective the surface is. As such the light at the top hits the top and keeps going straight because nothing is blocking it like with an aperture. As such it is mirrored because the light on the left of our field of view is bounced back from the left and the right on the right. I always thought that was obvious. It took me more time to understand why an aperture flipped things than it did for why a mirror didn't.

Now the reality is is it is flipped but not more than everything our eyes see is flipped out brains just flip it the right way so it is easier to interact with things.

Try to imagine this. You are standing in front of a revolving door hinged to a vertical axis at the center about which it can rotate. A picture of you is pasted on this door. Now if you flip the door, you will see an see an inverted (horizontally flipped) image of your picture. That is exactly how your reflection appears when you stand facing a mirror. Your image appears flipped about the vertical axis ('y-axis') and not about the axis pointing into the mirror ('z-axis').

You have come close but not properly explained the problem with mirrors...and left out the most interesting part.  The written words are left-right reversed because they are     asymmetrical in 2 dimensions. Rotating  a sheet of paper 180 degrees in 3D space left-right reverses an asymmetric 2D word or image. As you point out, for the mirror image of me to actually be me in 3D space it would have to have turned me inside-out...or rotated my body through the 4th dimension. There’s a better explanation: the image in the mirror is not just a reflection, it’s also a rotation. There is a 180 degree rotation within a plane, then a reflection about a perpendicular plane that is not the plane of the mirror. There are two ways to do this. Firstly, call the mirror the coronal plane. You can rotate in the transverse plane and reflect across the sagittal (the common conception - i.e. thinking of it as left-right flipped) or you can rotate in the sagittal plane and then reflect across the transverse plane (top-bottom flipped). So the answer is it’s both, or rather, one or the other depending on how you conceive of the object becoming the image.

I find this easier to understand as the three finger rule from electronics. It is similar to the arrows shown and you can do it anywhere.

Point towards the screen with your index finger on your right hand. Now point your middle finger to the left, and your thumb upwards.
Now, keeping your hand and fingers in the same shape, keep your thumb up and turn your hand to point at you. The thumb stays up but the other two fingers change direction. This means that your hand is rotating on the Z axis. To change vertically, start from the beginning and, keeping the middle finger pointed in the same direction, rotate your index finger back towards yourself.
Now your are rotating on the Y axis.

What a round the houses explanation of something so simple to explain.
1. The flat mirror is not a lens. So therefore a vertical and horizontal flip is not possible.
2. Photons leaving the body in the direction of the mirror are reflected back directly in the opposing direction. So Photons leaving a point on the left of the body reflects back from the corresponding point to the left of the mirror. The Photon at the top of the body does the same reflecting directly back to the top of the body. The same with the right side and the bottom and any other point on the body. Our eyes when looking at the mirror sees the point on the mirror directly opposite each point of the body as it is reflected directly back towards its point of origin.
3. In order to see our reflection as others see us the mirror would have to be vertically bent through and arch to enable the photons to cross at a point between the mirror and our eyes, an effect that can be seen at any fairground with a hall of mirrors feature.
4. Or purchase a concave shaving mirror position oneself at the appropriate distance from the mirror and see a full lens effect where the image is reflected flipped vertically AND horizontally.

Pretty good explanation. The "FOOD" sign is the best demonstration. The axis of reversal is the axis we use when we rotate the sign away from our eyes toward the mirror. She clearly shows that you CAN have vertical "reversal" instead of horizontal. Now the part she missed is the reason WHY we favor horizontal rotation. That is simply a matter of physiology. When we turn our eyes from what is before us to what is behind us, we turn side to side. We turn on a heel, turn our waist, turn our neck. Most of us would NOT get inverted by looking between our legs, or doing a handstand.

But it also has to do with our bilateral symmetry. That's a very good point. The mirror self actually ISN'T raising his left hand when I raise my right. It is still his right hand, just reversed on the Z dimension. If we did not have bilateral symmetry, we would not fall for that confusion.

No, the answer is much easier: Right and Left are "relative" directions, Up and Down are "absolute" directions. A mirror only flips relative directions.
So, if you choose up, down, west and east, which are all absolute directions, the mirror will change none of them.

The better question is, if we use "head side" and "feet side" as relative counterpart for up and down, the mirror never flips them, but why?

Okay "physics girl", how about you explain it using actual physics. It can all be explained by a simple ray diagram as shown here: https://d2gne97vdumgn3.cloudfront.net/api/file/7vp4dInQeea85ZmhdNQA.

The magnification of an image is defined by the equation m = -s'/s, where s is the distance from the object to the mirror, and s' is the distance from the image to the mirror. When the image appears to be "behind the mirror", as with any flat mirror, s' is negative. Therefore m = -(-s')/s, it's a double negative and m as a result is positive. When m is positive it appears to be going up from the center line, when m is negative it appears to go down from the center line.

This is also the reason why you look at a concave spoon and you appear upside down. (In the case of the spoon s' is on the same side as the object and so you have m = -s'/s, which then makes m negative and upside down.)

This video is good. But, I think an information conveyed here is wrong. The mirror image does not flip in any dimension/direction (not in Z direction too). In fact, it is a tool that helps us view an object's (2D) image in the same plane the object is in or without bringing the object in front of the eyes, because of its property to reflect light as it gets. It shows the 2-dimensional information of the object and not the 3-dimensional information. We should never try to understand the 3-dimensional property of object reflected on a mirror because it doesn't have it. It is just the 2D information of the object that is facing the mirror, in its original 2D plane. Our human brain needs the information to be in the opposite plane to us for us to perceive it using our eyes.

Reversed left to right, but not up and down, eh?
Try this.... stand in front of a mirror, extending your hands outward, noting the left-to-right difference.
Now, while still in front of the mirror, lean down on your left side, to lie down on a high bench, 90° from your vertical pose.
So now that your body is horizontal, extend your arms outward. They are now going up and down.
Note that the "reversal" is now oriented in the up-and-down axis, NOT left-to-right.
It's our sense of relative interpretation, lightly (but not completely) touched on in this video.

Sorry, there is no Z axis in a 2 dimensional reflection, but perspective results in an apparent depth because you're looking  at the 2 dimensional reflection from off axis. If the arrow was exactly on axis and you could look at it's reflection exactly on that axis you wouldn't see any apparent depth - the arrow would appear as a straight line, just as if you looked at the arrow itself exactly along the axis of the arrow.

They don't flip anything. It's just that we choose to rotate our bodies towards the mirror on a horizontal plane. Therefore we treat the Z zero point as our plane of symmetry origin.

Its the way our Eyes perceive directions which is flipped. Its the way, we make sense out of left and right is being flipped. If you divide the mirror into 1 Million Horizontal sections and/or I million vertical sections. As if each section is a microscopic Pixel. Then each pixel is just reflecting its own self. 




The terms Horizontal and Vertical are relative to the Object and the Observer. So, if we are talking about the Mirror, then if the same girl changes her posture in front of the mirror from standing to sleeping, Then Mirror will Flip her VERTICALLY, instead of HORIZONTALLY. Now this Vertical, Horizontal Plane is with respect to the Mirror. 




But, from her individual perspective, Her body would still be flipped Horizontally Instead of vertical. This happens BECAUSE, HER EYES and OUR EYES are a Pair of Camera Lenses Attached HORIZONTALLY on Our face instead of Vertically. So, our perception while understanding Horizontal and Vertical Flip needs a bit more PRACTICE. 




If she is lying in the sleeping posture, in front of the mirror. Her eyes are perceiving her Body to be flipped in the SAME HORIZONTAL way, in which they are perceiving it to be flipped when she is standing. But, this SLEEPING Horizontal FLIP is actually a FLIP in the direction which would be considered as the STANDING VERTICAL FLIP. 
And Now when we, as observers and audience are still standing and observing her sleeping posture. HER EYES are VERTICALLY ALIGNED (One on top of the other) With respect to US. So, to us Thats a Vertical Flip, with respect to us. But, to her thats a horizontal flip with respect to her own eyes.

The answer has nothing to do with physics or geometry. The reason why mirrors "flip" things left and right and forwards and backwards and not up and down has to do with the way we think and talk.

Mirrors "flip" directions that are relative to the way the viewer looks at it - left and right and forward and backward are relative to the viewer but up and down and east and west are not. If we face each other, what is on my left is on your right, also without a mirror. What I see as east you also see as east, what I see as up you also see as up, with or without a mirror.

Mirrors do not flip anything. Left and right with regards to your self, depend on what way You are facing. The left or right side of say, a room, are usually based upon the entry point. Now back to a mirror. If you hold a red ball in your left hand, and a green in your right and approach a mirror, it may seem to you that the mirror image has a red ball in its right hand, but this is your mind projecting a perspective on the mirror image's world, which doesn't really exist. The reflection doesn't have a left hand, YOU do. If you go away, it has no hand at all. If you set the red ball down in front of the mirror in front of your left hand, the ball is on the left, and its reflection is also on YOUR left. The mirror doesn't have a perception of left and right, as it cannot perceive. We tend to project an identity to the reflection because we see a person there.

That doesn't mean a mirror CAN'T flip the vertical direction.
The real reason is that mirrors are mounted vertically on walls.

If the mirror is x,y (horizontal, vertical) and the perpendicular to the mirror is z, and the person is standing vertically in the y direction, it is the z direction that gets flipped. Following the z axis into the mirror the back of the person is followed by the front of the person, followed by the image of the front, not the back, representing a 180 rotation around the y axis. So although the reflected right and left eyes are on the left and right they are in opposite positions from where they should be in the actual person facing in the direction that appears in the mirror.

But to do this VERTICAL FLIP the mirror must be horizontal (x, z) and it is then the y (vertical) axis that is perpendicular to the mirror and it is that that is flipped, and the feet will appear nearest, at the top and the head at the farthest or the bottom. You can test this explanation yourself by placing a mirror on the floor under a transparent table and standing a doll on it. The reflection will show the doll standing on its head.

Why a person in a mirror has switched horizontal sides (left arm is right and right is left) but not vertical?

Because that is how we define them. We've agreed that we will differentiate sides of a human body in respect to its head and (let's say) chest. In physics terms we could say that the right side is a cross product of front (chest) and up (head). Take a starfish for example and tell which of its arm is right or left. Thus reflection of a starfish has everything in place (or everything wrong based on your way to think of this).

With top and bottom it is different. The top of a body is where its head is. So it's kind of an absolute property of a human body. It could be somewhat confusing since we often alternatively tell top from bottom in relation to Earth but it's irrelevant regarding mirror reflections.

Wow. The people who find this to be common sense, or prefer the idea that there is no question at all ("it's a reflection; nothing flips") are either Feynman-level geniuses or being willfully obtuse. When you are watching TV or a movie with someone else and they complain about what a character did, do you explain to them that you are not really watching people at all, just photons emitted from the TV screen? What fun that must be.

What PG is talking about is the perception--that I would have thought almost anyone has experienced--that if someone were, like Alice through the looking-glass, to inhabit the person who appears to be them behind the surface of the mirror, their "right hand" would be on the left side of their body, etc., but their head would still be on top and their feet on the ground. (I am assuming a vertical mirror looked at directly, the overwhelmingly "normal" situation.)

So the question, which I think PG explained well, is why that fictional person in the mirror appears to be you "flipped" horizontally, but not vertically. One way to get at this might have been to talk about standing on mirrors, or looking at mirrors on the ceiling, as some commenters have indicated. In one way I can see how this gets more directly at the idea that the "flip" is not necessarily horizontal, but I would suggest without proof that if PG were to have done either of these she would have ended up with more sexist comments than she has already, and who needs that?

Including a friend with an R and L on her hands was a good technique, as was the arrow. The commenter xeno rama helped me think about this further by their suggestion that turning 90 degrees from the mirror (and, crucially, turning your left-right frame of reference at the same time, so that "forward" is parallel to the face of the mirror) causes the left hand (with the L) of the "person in the mirror" to appear on their right. In this case the image-person has truly been left-right flipped. This shows that the key is distance from the mirror. (Or position along the z-axis, as PG would probably say.) So what I would suggest that PG add would be a shot where she moves her say, right hand closer to the mirror, perhaps in front of her left hand (both straight in front of her). Then she could talk about how her real right hand is further away from her body, while her mirror-image right hand is closer to her (real) body. Maybe something like that could help illustrate that the nature of the mirror image is front-to-back, not horizontal.

The shape causes the image we see to be flipped inside our eyeballs both horizontally and vertically. The brain has to interpret the image back to its proper orientation. The light actually hits the back of the eye rotated upside down.

Your premise is invalid. The mirror does flip the image no matter what the angle. If you rotate your FOOD sign 90 degrees L or R to vertical, it still shows DOOF. For the most part, this is not a "physics" issue.

Sensory perception psychology is key to understanding this issue. For example, the image signals from the eyes to the brain indicates the world is upside down. Fortunately, the image signal processing in the brain (along with the sensory inner ear to indicate upwards orientation) interprets the image to coincide with the real outside world. Most telling are individuals who have suffered injuries to the brain. To some of these people, the world is sideways or perhaps upside down!

As to why the brain doesn't appear to flip a vertically reflected image some other direction...you'll have to ask the Designers!

Background, I've learned about reflection, lenses, everything optics before university level, basically. And I do remember how this stuff works, maybe requiring a bit of thinking here and there. However, I read this title and realised... I didn't know. Sure, I know a mirror just works by redirecting light a certain way and all, but why exactly does that copy happen to be the exact horizontal reflection of what a friend would see if they looked at us instead of us at our own reflection?
My first instinct was to think about how what we see is actually a vertically flipped (or was it turned 180º?), image seen by our eyes which is corrected by our brain... Of course I got lost. But this video, with its simple explanation, made me understand.

This comment is for everyone who thinks this video is for 'idiots'. It's not necessarily: of course people who didn't know about mirrors yet will learn too, but sometimes, you know so much stuff that in looking for an answer you stumble on that in trying to find an answer... When the right question to ask is deceptively simple ("How would I need to move in order to get to the position my reflection is in, facing the same way it is?").

And in case people still doubt whether it's not just idiocy... 2 days ago I created rules for some geometric figures on how to "upscale" them to 1 dimension higher. Granted, this is actually why I err in physics: abstract math is my playground, add real world components and I lose my balance.
And why is my head only half as large as it is when I look in the mirror?

•A mirror in front of you only flips you front-to-back. If you move up, your reflection moves up; if you move to the right, your reflection moves to the right. If you move forward, your reflection moves toward your rear (the opposite direction).
•A mirror on your left only flips you left-to-right. If you move up, your reflection moves up; if you move forward, your reflection moves forward. If you move to the left, your reflection moves to the right (the opposite direction).
•A mirror above you only flips you top to bottom. If you move to the right, your reflection moves to the right; if you move forward, your reflection moves forward. If you move up, your reflection moves down (the opposite direction).

This is just more confusing. Think about the "image" in a mirror being the result of points extending from you out to the mirror. To simplify things, let's say there's a point for your head, a point for each hand, and a point for each foot. If we look at our rudimentary mirror, we'll see five points mapped onto it. Now, let's repeat this process with say, a trillion points, each representing some tiny segment of you. Map it out, and you have something approaching a reflection. Do this again, and again, and again with more points. Keep doing this, and you'll get what we perceive as a reflection.

How to turn something simple into a mess of confusion.

Mirrors reflect light. What you see in a mirror depends on the angle at which you are looking in relation to the mirror. If you are standing directly in front of the mirror, the light traveling from your body is reflected straight back at you at a 90 degree angle from the surface of the mirror. Therefore, the light from the right side of your body travels straight at the right side of the mirror and the light from the left side of your body travels straight at the left side of the mirror. The reason it looks backwards is the result of the light traveling back from the mirror to our eyes. We perceive our left and right sides still on their respective sides, but facing us, which gives the illusion that our image has been flipped.
Mirror reflects light, end of video.

It's simple. Mirrors don't reverse left & right or up & down. They reverse front & back. That's because the light hits the mirror going forward and then comes back at you as it is reflected by the mirror. The reason we think it reverses right & left is because we are used to facing people who are looking back at us. They are the ones who are reversing their right & left as they look at us, and why we cross our right hand to the left to shake hands. Our mirror image does not do this and this can be confusing.

Because mirrors don't flip horizontally. They flip "front to back".  If you stand in front of a mirror, facing north, and point east, your image will point east. If you point west, your image will point west. But if you point north, towards the mirror, your image will point south towards you. The axis that is reversed in a mirror is the axis that passes through the mirror at right angles, not the up and down or side to side axis. It is like reaching into a sock and pulling it inside out towards you. The left side is still on the left, the right side is till on the right and the top and bottom are still top and bottom, but the toe is not pointing towards you instead of away from you. It's the Z axis that is reversed.

It's not because you flip them horizontally. It's because (as you said) it is flipped along the Z axis. i.e. pulled inside out like a glove. Left is left, up is up, right is right down is down. BUT, front is back. the only flipping being done is front to back.

A mirror doesn't "flip" anything. Left and right are relative terms. The "flipping" happens, because the viewer changes their imagined orientation to that of their mirror image and thereby changes their left/right orientation. Also, you can have a mirror "flip" vertically. Just hold the mirror at a horizontal orientation in front of you. Now the ceiling appears in the mirror to be "on the floor." Or, think of the reflection of trees and mountains in a very still lake surface... the trees and mountains in the lake reflection appear to "point down." Of course this is also just a matter of your relative position. Stand on your head and look at the lake reflection and the reflected trees and mountains "point up."

Glad to see that someone else also wondered about this horizontal flip and made a video about it. My explanation was kind of the same: you believe that the person in the mirror is just facing you as if they had made their way round the mirror. So you assume a rotation of 180 degrees along the vertical axis. But the mirror does a flip of the depth instead. What you end up seeing is the difference between your assumption and what you see. A rotation along the vertical axis is equivalent of flipping horizontally and flipping the depth. So the difference between the two transformations is a horizontal flip.

If you don't want to flip the image, it's like if you drew 'food' with a brand new, thick felt pen that bled through the paper to it's back .. If you then hold up the paper, you can see 'food' in the paper, and 'food' in it's reflection, When you flip it horizontally, you then see 'doof' on both the paper and the reflection.
So, when you're looking at the paper in the mirror after 'flipping it so you can see it', you're no longer looking at it with the lef side on the left side. you're looking at it with the right side on the left side.. and you're looking at it's 'back'.

Here's another way of looking at it: when you look in the mirror, the hand on the left in the mirror corresponds to your left hand, and the hand on the right in the mirror corresponds to your right hand, so everything is really okay.

Now if you are facing north as you look into the mirror, your real nose is facing northward, but the nose in the reflection is facing SOUTHWARD! So in effect, the mirror flips front for back and not up for down and not side for side.

Since we know that people really don't get squashed in the mirror and flipped backwards for frontwards, we "interpret" the image as looking as though it flips our image horizontally.

A lot of confusion stems from the ambiguous word 'flip'.  Rotation (e.g. 'flipping over' a piece of paper) and reflection (what happens to light when it hits a mirror) are two fundamentally different transformations, regardless of which direction they happen in.

This video did not exactly get it. We have a bias of our sense of direction. Most of the time up stays up, down stays down and we pivot around on our feet so our sense of left to right and right to left can pivot around. Left to us is our left but it could be in the direction of east, north, west, south. We change the direction of left but still call it left. If we stood on our head we would no longer call the direction our head is pointing, up. The mirror just reflects back. We treat left and right as directions. If we lived on a wall and pivoted around on our left hands instead, some times our feet would be up and sometimes our heads would face down. If we continued to insist that our heads pointed up and our feet pointed down, then mirrors would seem to flip vertically, not horizontally.

Construct an orthogonal basis in the plane of the mirror and perpendicular to the mirror. The mirror constructs the image that preserves the axes parallel to the surface and reverses the perpendicular axis. A mirror in front of you preserves left and right, up and down, but reverses front and back. Put the mirror to one side and front and back are preserved but left and right. Stand on and top and bottom are reversed.

One way you could put this, too, is to prove that there isn't actually any horizontal flipping occurring at all: The mirror image of your top half is still above the bottom half, so no vertical flipping. However, the image of your right hand is STILL to the right of the image of your left hand. Therefore, NO horizontal flipping either, exactly like the vertical axis. A bathroom door to your left is still to your left when viewed in the mirror, another example of there being no horizontal flipping. If you put a mirror on the floor and stand on it, then you have vertical flipping, as up becomes down. But left is still left, and forward is still forward. If while facing a mirror, you simply turn to the right, suddenly the image of your right hand is not only on your left, but to the left of the image of your left hand.

When I teach this subject I simply say that a mirror does not change the location of the image. If the plane mirror goes up and down and east and west, the east side of the image stays on the east side. Right and left are relative terms which depend on direction. When facing a different direction right and left have different meanings. Since the mirror does not change the locactional side of the image, the relative direction becomes backwards.

She might have been more clear in demonstrating this way: If you write on the mirror, it does not 'flip' your writing, even if you carefully look at the reflected letters (~1/4" behind your written letters). Likewise, if you write on a transparent surface anywhere between you and the mirror, both sets of characters (original or in the mirror) are perfectly normal whether written left-to-right, or top-to-bottom (assuming European writing, but it doesn't really matter.)
If you then flip the surface around (as if it were a shirt or someone else had written it on your forehead), either way (up/down or left/right), it is then flipped in the mirror too.
Obvious, with subtle implications for being inside our clothes and our eyes & heads ;-).
All of the above is true when facing the mirror, whether you are standing on your feet or head, or lying on your right or left side (or any orientation between these).

If U is a vector pointing in your "up" direction and F is a vector pointing in your "forward" direction, then your "right" direction (R) is defined by the cross-product R = F x U.

Mirrors reverse the direction normal to the mirror, which is F if you're facing it. -F x U = -R = L. So, your right will correspond to your reflection's left.

The easier way to explain How mirrors work is like this :

~Mirrors do not 'flip' images. They merely show exactly what is directly in front of them, at every given point on their surface. So as far as vertically, your head is not seen where your feet are, and visa versa, because they reflect directly in front of where their location it, in the reflective surface. Yet your right hand is on the reflection's left side, because that too is exactly where it is before the mirrors surface... there is no real vertical or horizontal in reflections.

{Over-thought explanation}Think of a mirror/reflective surface like a wall, and the light that carries your(or a) images as a series of balls. If you throw a ball at the right part of the wall, it does not bounce back at you from the left side of the wall... the same goes for every particle of light (or ball) at every point on the Wall/or Mirror~ {Over-thought explanation}

The question is a thought game, devised to make you rethink something you might normally just take for granted, due to the self evidence of the natural physics of it. Not many people would wonder why mirrors flip images, unless asked why and given complex reasons to why..hence leaving most, more confused about it, then they started off as. These sorts of questions are devised dishonestly as filler for video content at the least... for being so easy to explain, and yet going off on a maze-bending journey of explanations, to confuse the logic out of people who might have figured it out for themselves, had the question never been posed...

The "horizontal flip" but not "vertical" is a non-issue, as is the "my forward, your backward". Reflection is about light: no light = no reflection. We all know what a shade is in that a shadow is merely a darkened patch where an object is blocking its sunlight. Apart from the fact that a shade is a continuous dark tone, its properties are consistent with a mirror reflection (the left hand is raised when the sun is behind the person, but the shadow raises its right hand). A reflection in a pond is exactly the same but here there is more detail which enables you to distinguish some colour thereby seeing your teeth which the sunlight reflection prevents you from doing. Therefore, in a lit up room within a house, a clean mirror's reflection should produce identical colour and detail - but those colours are merely chunks of shade cast upon the glass. This is the reason.

Take a solid F made up from Styrofoam, as example, you see an F and the mirror reflect... a perfect F, un-flipped. Mirror does not flip things. You can flip something by taking all of the X coordinates and multiplying by -1.
Or you can do it with Y or Z coordinates too. All of them will cause left and right to change places like the mirror image. It does not matter even if you flip it around some arbitrary plane in 3 dimensions which is not parallel to any of your coordinate axes. Left and right get interchanged. When you look in the mirror your eyes see the rays that reflected off it, which actually came from another direction, which got reversed (probably can think of it as the z direction), but you see an image as if it were really behind the mirror, the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front. So if the mirror is at zero and the objects in front of it have positive z coordinates, then the image's objects have negative z coordinates. This is a flip and left and right are reversed. And if you flip twice, it is back to normal. So if you flip an odd number of times then it is reversed, even number of flips is back to normal. So if you hold a reversed transparent page with text up to the mirror the text will look normal. Or if you reflect an object off two mirrors it goes back to normal.

I've always seen it as, "The mirror reverses to and from, not left and right". Just write something on a piece of clear plastic and then hold it up in front of a mirror so you can read it. Notice that the direction of text hasn't changed but you're seeing the back side of the plastic in the mirror rather than the front. Or put a compass in front of a mirror which faces south. East still points east and west still points west, but north and south (to and from) have been reversed. The mental aspect is that our minds presuppose that if we were standing on the other side of the mirror looking back at ourselves, we would have rotated 180° about the vertical axis.

Another way of saying it (or seeing it) is that the left-right flip is in your mind. (or language centre) The words left and right (as well as forward and backward) are relative to your body, while up and down are relative to the earth or gravity. You would never say that a left-handed person was actually a down-headed person doing a foot-stand, would you? You never have kids who can't seem to remember which shoe to put on their down foot. I think Physics Girl's Z-reversal  (front to back reversal) is the best answer.   With translucent paper, look at the supposed right to left reversal by the mirror, and move the paper right up to the surface of the mirror.  Right left is not reversed.  What is reversed is the z direction - "towards the mirror" becomes "away from the mirror" and vice versa.  You present paper with ink side further from your eyes than the back side of the paper.   It presents to you paper with the ink side closer to your eyes.  This turns each letter "inside out" regardless of which way the paper against the mirror is oriented!

I can clearly see from this video that you understand what's going on; reversal in the z direction causes a parity reversal, and this is interpreted as inverting left and right instead of up and down because of... convention.

Martin Gardner addressed this in "The Ambidextrous Universe", of course.

But I think that many people would need a more careful, simpler explanation to understand and not be confused. For example, you could put the mirror on the North wall of a room, and then point out that, just as Up and Down are not reversed, East and West aren't reversed either. Front and Back are reversed - and since left and right are defined by the relationship between Up and Front, rather than being absolute directions like East and West, then in one sense they are reversed.

Of course, the fact that you're comparing your reflection with you turning around rather than you doing a handstand is another way to explain this - but it needs to be made more obvious.

The mirror doesn't flip anything. It reflects. Hence the word "reflection." What is to our left will always be seen to our left in the mirror, which is what appears to be to the right of our own reflection. It's as simple as that. And this is also why what is higher will be seen higher in the mirror, and therefor a "vertical flip" isn't possible.

Take this one step further: lie down and look in the mirror that way. Up will still be up, no matter on which side your lying.

Take it even further than that and look at the Moon. Some morons claim the Moon is fake, and that it changes during the night. One of them noticed that the Moon had flipped upside-down during the night. That the side of the Moon which was on the north side - to the left - at moonrise was still on the north side - to the right - at moonset seemed to escape his notice...

And even though the Moon is in no way like a mirror, it does show that the only "flipping" is in our mind, used to seeing everything from our personal perspective.

There may be an interesting way to understand this. Think about optical isomers  (chirality) of chemical compounds. If a certain object has no plane of symmetry then it is impossible to overlap it with its mirror image. So given the fact that the human body isn't perfectly symmetric (the right and left sides are a little different) so it has no symmetry plane, it is impossible to overlap with your mirror image. No matter how you flip yourself you can't be like your mirror image:) This is why the glove had to be turned inside out. Rotation and translation is not enough. So the interesting fact is that your mirror image it's actually a different version of yourself that can't be reproduced in any other way ! :)

Mirrors don't flip anything. Face a mirror and stick out your right arm straight out to the right. Light hits your arm and bounces off your arm and then hits the right side of the mirror and bounces right back to your eye. Same is true for left side, top and bottom. Light bounces off the left side and bounces back to your eye. Top bounces back and bottom bounces back. It doesn't flip them.

Here is another example without using a mirror but a blank white wall. Put a lamp or other light source behind you so you see your shadow on the wall and stick out your right arm straight out. Light from the lamp will be blocked by your arm but light that isn't blocked will hit the wall making it brighter while area being blocked by your arm will be darker creating your shadow. The light then bounces back off the wall and into your eye. Obviously the shadow on the wall's right arm is sticking straight out. But since mirrors are so much better at bouncing light back the light hitting the our bodies facing the mirror bounces off our bodies hits the mirror and bounces straight back. So light hitting your right arm bounces off your arm hits the right side of the mirror and bounces straight back.

Thank you for this video, I think it helped me more fully to understand why we get confused by this seemingly simple problem. It's more well presented and examining every case (from humans to written words) than other videos I have seen on the same question (I watched Richard Feynman's answer before, explained the human psychological aspect but not the word flips). Well, yes one can think it with how reflection works, but it's a counter-intuitive problem that still can confuse even the logical minds. So, I am surprised to see people writing comments like "Problem is simple, you are all idiots". There are interesting insights in why we confuse problems like this and that's more important than "come on it's common logic, get over it", and that even teaches us how we think in science and how easily we can fall into fallacies (remember also the Monty Hall problem).

Excellent video. I'd like to add just one thing: Gravity. That's why we flip things "horizontally" (around a vertical axis). When we walk and turn we do it about a vertical axis, resulting in horizontal "flipping". Turning things upside down is much less common, and so stands out more. And the vertical bilateral symmetry is why a vertical flip of yourself, reversing top and bottom, looks so much different than a horizontal flip, reversing left and right. Gravity also has more consequences for turning things upside down than it does for turning them horizontally (about a vertical axis), making the two seem rather different. (For example, you might get dizzy being turned upside down, but not from turning left or right.) But as for just the reversals, they are just equivalent things done in different directions. Cool!

Because gravity! Gravity holds us to the earth's surface forcing us to make most of our movements horizontally (ish). In a  normal day we turn many times about our own vertical axis and the language we use reflects that. Left and right are relative to ourselves, whereas up and down are absolutes. We automatically adjust our frame of reference when talking to others because we know their left and right is not orientated the same as ours. We then anthropomorphise our mirror image, treating it as another person and calling the reflection of our right hand the mirror image's left hand. There is actually no paradox. When you wave your right hand, the hand of the reflection on the right of the mirror waves, as you would expect.

thanks for trying. but this video doesn't truly answer the question. and some of the things you stated are just not so. let me explain: keep assuming x/y/z are in relation to you standing up on a level floor. take into account that we ASSUME a mirror (a 2-D surface) is mounted vertically. since it can't reflect on the axis it is oriented to (vertical, {"y" according to the frame at 1:38} when mounted on a wall), it can only reflect and thus, reverse on the horizontal axes (forward and back "z", and left-right "x"). should you mount the mirror to the floor, you will see vertical flipping. by aligning the plane to the "z" axis, you'd lose your "z" reversal for the gain in "y" reversal. if we try to align the plane to the "x" axis, we get no reflection because we are on the "x" axis. we 3-D beings can't see the edge of a 2-D plane.

The short answer is that height is the dimension in which we are anchored to the ground by gravity, and width then becomes an extra “free” dimension (while depth is the basic dimension you look “forward” in). So when we want to reverse “back and forth”, the dimension we turn in is always right or left. As the video mentions, we have a symmetry in this free dimension, but not in height, where our feet and legs are on the bottom to stand on, and our heads are on top. We could “turn around” the second way (like a half somersault), but that would mean standing on our heads (or hands).
Up and down are the same for everyone, where left and right are not. So we end up totally geared toward width, like in reading and writing.

With a mirror, the light from left, right up and down heads straight from you, to the mirror, and then bounces back to you, in the same position. This flips back/forth without flipping any of the other two dimensions. So we end up with a negative image, (one dimension reversed). Like multiplying positive or negative humbers, an odd number of negatives is negative, but an even number is positive.

If we lived on a vertically oriented "world" (like on the side of a vertical surface and gravity still pulled "down", but we had a way of clinging onto this surface and moving around it, like insects), and had freedom in the vertical dimension, when "turning around" to see someone else, we would always see words upside down and reverse from our perspective. So looking in a mirror, we would still see the same negative image, but expecting it to be upside down and backwards, we would only see it as backwards, so that width seems normal, but height seems flipped (i.e. to what we're used to seeing).

A great way to illustrate this is with a clear plastic sheet (like projector sheets) that you write on, then hold it up to the mirror. If you orient the sheet so that you can read it in real life, you'll notice you can also read it in the mirror. This is because you haven't made any flips at all, so it remains readable.

To take it one step further, we can imagine a clear blue sheet that we write on with solid red letters. To our eyes, the letters on the sheet we are holding will appear red, but if we read the word on the mirror, the word will appear purple, because the light has to go through the clear blue sheet before it hits the red words. This really drives home the fact that it's a front-back flip (z-axis) flip that the mirror produces, and any other flip only comes from you flipping yourself around.

This is a complicated (and somewhat confusing) explanation for a VERY simple question.

The truth is they don't "flip" anything. Mirrors reflect what is right in front of them. Your head reflects where your head is. Your feet reflects where your feet are. Your right hand shows up in front of your right hand and your left hand does the same! Humans have bilateral symmetry meaning you can split us evenly down the center and have 2 equal halves (for the most part). What if we didn't have bilateral symmetry? Like a starfish (radial symmetry)! Place a starfish in front of a mirror and each arm will reflect directly back at itself! This is not caused by the mirror, because you can rotate a mirror on a wall without changing the image. Try placing the mirror on a table or the floor. It still reflects what is right in front of it (or directly above). Humans and starfish have arms, what if you set something on the mirror that didn't have arms? Like a cardboard tube. Every point on that cardboard tube will reflect directly back at itself!

This is not a difficult topic.

The mirror doesn't flip. The image appears flipped because you are viewing it from the front. You should be viewing it from the BACK, the way your image in the mirror views it. For more math inclined people: the operation of flipping along z can be decomposed to rotation by 180 degrees around the y axis followed by a flip along x (or first flip along x and then rotate around y).

In other words, the mirror actually flips along z, but the image looks too similar to a 180 degree rotation along y. So we are left to wonder only the "extra" part of the operation of the mirror, that is the flip along x.

There is another great visualization which would help clarify. Take that original piece of paper with "FOOD" written on it.

Had you written it on a transparent surface and held that up, you would see EXACTLY what was reflected in the mirror. If you hold the transparent surface stationary and walk around to the other side, the work appears inverted but still looks correct (behind you) in the mirror. In this way you can put yourself "between" the reflection and see the "flip" happen. Walk back to the original side and the image unflips. All right in front of you. Nothing in the mirror changes, instead you flip the original real object in the z-axis.

There's a simpler way to visualize this. A reflected image is an image formed by drawing the shortest possible line from each point of the object to the mirror surface (which is essentially the path taken by light bouncing off the object to the mirror). Perpendicular lines are always the shortest - so by drawing a series of perpendicular lines from the object, we realize that any other representation of the image other than a z-axis flipped mirror image would require beams of light to travel longer distances compared to the perpendicular distance, hence it would be unnatural. This also explains distortions in our reflection when we stand in front of curved or wavy mirror surfaces.
If anyone is still confused, I think Richard Feynman explained it more concisely more effectively.
