Yargh.  I don't think this was simplified enough.  The best way to show what happens is to stand in front of a mirror, and then "project" a transparent slide of yourself onto the surface of a mirror, just as if you were a slide.  Your image on the mirror will be flipped in the same way an image can be flipped in a projector.  Even though you are pretending to be a slide with a light behind you, you are actually a "mirror" of sorts yourself, reflecting light onto the other mirror.  Light bounces off your body and lands on the mirror in the same order it came off you, and it recreates a flipped image, because the light is reflected from your "surface".

First of all, mirrors can reflect images not just horizontally but also vertically and diagonally and even, an uneven trajectory. How? as the video fails to mention, it depends on the shape and placement of the mirror. There is no actual 3d space in the mirror as we see it, hence there is no strict horizontal and vertical values of it. it's an illusion. and the illusion is different if you place a mirror ball on the ground and looking at it with different angles. you get the idea.

To simply explain what happens; a mirror like properties redirects photons according to their trajectory, velocity and the angle that hits the surface. What you see in the mirror is a ray of redirected photons that are specifically reaching to your eyes. Hence you see the virtual visual of reflected surface which happens to be on your reflected looking angle. In this case, yourself and your surroundings. A ray of light that hits the mirror with a 90 degree angle is redirected with a 90 degree angle. Other one that comes with a 45 degree is redirected with a 135 degree angle. and so on. When combined, the extends of a form of rays of light would seem flipped to our eyes as they cross each other when they are reflected. Basic Optics. Draw an imaginary guide lines from your eyes towards the extends of the object that you see in the mirror, then follow the direction according to the reflected angles. & vice versa.

fun fact: the only point that you actually directly look on the mirrors (meaning with 90 degree angle) is where you look into your eyes on it.

The thing happening with mirrors has to do with light and how the surface of mirrors reflects it. Normal mirrors like that, flat, reflects the light beam in "straight angles". So what we see is exactly the same image as shown to the mirror. Without any flipping (even in a z direction). If you stay in your left side to the mirror it will reflect just the same side, not other (right side), what would be a "z reversion". Take a concave mirror, for example, the lights beam will cross in front of it, after the focus point, and we will be able to see a "normal spelling" in phrases and other things will appear like normal. Because what is shown to the mirror will be reversed before coming up to our eyes. This don't happen in flat mirrors.

I love the explanation that the mirror really only flips "in vs. out".  The demonstration with the arrow really drives that home.

One thing to add:  When we rotate ourselves by 180° to view the sign, we are flipping both the x and z axes.  This undoes the mirror's flipping of "in vs. out" (the z-axis) and adds the flipping of "left vs. right" (the x-axis).  If you hold a clear sign up so that you can read it, you'll be able to read both the original and the reflection at the same time.  That's why you can read your own rear window stickers via your mirror.

I believe the answer can be more succinctly explained with some math.
What we call "forward" is an absolute direction, where the eyes are looking towards ("z" in the video)
What we call "up" is an absolute direction, where our head stands.
What we call "left" is relative direction, equal to the cross product of "up" and "forward". If you think of it, there is no other precise definition of what "left" is.
Then, "left in the mirror world" is, by definition, equal to "up in the mirror world", cross "forward in the mirror world", but since "forward in the mirror world" is equal to minus "forward in the real world" (as pointed out with the paper arrow in the video), then "left in the mirror world" is equal to "right in the real world" because of properties of the cross product: U x F = - (U x (-F) )

It's not 'flipping', it's reflection - a simple one-to-one (not counting multiple directions of reflected light) reflection. So, raise right hand, and in the mirror it's the right hand's reflection that is raised. It only looks like the left hand because the human axis of symmetry is vertical so it appears like you're looking at a person facing you, when it would be their left hand. Being face-to-face and human symmetry may be hard wired into the brain by evolution, but mirrors are not, so the psychological effect is the same as being face-to-face with someone raising their left hand as you raise your right.

No offence Physics Girl, but this is a really bad explanation. I understand you're trying to keep it simple so as many people as possible understand, but in doing so you managed to make this mirror thing more complicated than needs be.

I'll explain it:

Light rays from an object placed in front of a plane mirror are reflected according to the law of reflection so that they form a VIRTUAL image of the object 'behind' the mirror. 
Law of reflection= The Incident ray (Light ray being 'presented' to the mirror) is reflected of the mirror surface to produce the reflected ray. The angle at which the incident ray meets the mirror (angle of incidence)is equal to the angle which the reflected ray leaves (angle of reflection). <---- If you don't understand what i said here, Google it. 

A ray diagram (again, Google it) shows that the rays reflected off the mirror are diverging and look like they come from 'behind' the mirror. This is the position of the image produced by the mirror, and it is called a Virtual image (because light rays dont come from behind the mirror, they are reflected from the surface. They only look like they come from behind the mirror where the object is).

 An accurate scale drawing, diagram or even an experiment  shows that the virtual image is the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front, and a line joining the object and the image is perpendicular to the surface of the mirror (perpendicular means that the angle between the line and mirror surface is 90 degrees [right-angle]. This better explains how the arrow points backwards in the mirror.

So, as explained, the virtual image is :
-Upright (not vertically inverted)
-Points of object are as far 'into' the mirror as it is away from it, so the virtual image is the same shape as the object.
-Laterally inverted (So if I raise my right leg, the virtual image looks like it raises its left leg)

TL;DR: Mirror doesn't do any flipping, it's just light rays being reflected from the surface, which produces a laterally inverted image.

The mirror is not flipping anything and it's not because we are "presenting things horizontally". It's simply light reflecting back in the opposite direction that it hits the mirror. That's it. So, of course, things will appear to be "flipped" when that light bounces back. If you bounce a ball off a wall then it's going to bounce back in the opposite direction from that same point that it hits the wall. The same happens with light on a mirror.

Our feet don't appear to be where our heads are (her so-called Y-axis flip) because the reflected light bounces back at the shortest distance that it originates from. A basketball bounces back from the same point it hits the wall...  Wondering why a mirror reflects the way that it does is like punching the mirror on the right side and being confused that it didn't crack on the left side instead. It doesn't make any sense and her explanation of this effect made even less sense.

This isn't the rocket science that she makes it out to be in the video. It's simply light bouncing back at us on the same point that it hits on the mirror. Simple as that.

The explanation about why left-right and up-down seems so different: up-down is absolute while left-right is an interpretation depending on the object.  All absolute directions remain the same in a mirror image. Point up, down, east, west, ... and the mirror image will also point in that direction.  But left and right are properties of an object.  The mirror object is not the same as the original, but indeed flipped along the z-axis.  The flipped thing you see in the mirror does not exist in the real world and it has left & right flipped.

Describing a mirror image as a flip may cause further confusion. To understand mirrors, you have to understand the basic physics of light. A mirror, by definition, reflects photons at the angle of incident. For example, take the food sign, hold it up to a light as if you were holding it up to a mirror, and look at the back side of the page so you are looking behind the text. You are seeing what the mirror would see, a reversed image, which is the photons reflected at the angle of incidence. Mystery solved. For further explanation I recommend reading this article: http://science.howstuffworks.com/innovation/everyday-innovations/mirror2.htm

Fail. I was sooo hopeful that the video would live up to the promise of its title. Alas. I have indeed wondered for this years. I can visualize in my mind the physics, but it us hard to translate into words. And while you've done a great job of explaining what ISNT happening, you've done a poor job of what IS.
Take for instance your T shirt, "I <3 Physics". In the mirror, it's clearly reading backwards, but not because you flipped it. If you were to stand at a 90-degree angle to the mirror, with the camera at an iso angle to you both, the word would appear horizontally flipped but not vertically. It has nothing to do with your flipping it.

Of in the above scenario, you hold the arrow to your right, it will appear to the viewers to point to our left, but the mirror will show you pointing to our right.

The above phenomena are actually the z-axis flipping at work. But that explains nothing of interest. The Z axis flipping should result in the appearance of a vertical flip. And given the right angles, it does.

Imagine the mirror if place above your head, with its x-axis at 90 degrees (incidental) to the camera, but with its y-axis 45-degree downward tilt. Do we viewers see you vertically flipped, horizontally flipped, or both? The answer is both! See for instance http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fc/Cloud_Gate_boy_reflection.jpg

So by changing the mirror's placement and angle, we can affect whether or not the vertical axis is flipped, but we can't change whether or not the horizontal is flipped.

There is something else going on here, something not explained by "scisyhp" (nor by magic) but (I suspect) by a component of the brain.

And thus with baited breath I await from you a clearer explanation.

Appreciate the effort but this is neither a good approach nor explanation. It complicates the matter unnecessarily, and the explanation is not that accurate.

- Since we are not two dimensional objects on a computer screen, it makes more sense to label our reflection against a PLANE rather than an AXIS considering we are three-dimensional objects - it really is not intuitive to be reflected on an "x axis" since three planes (mirrors) can pass through that axis, or an infinite number if they are not pre-defined.  

- A mirror - or a reflective 2-dimensional plane by two axes here - simply "flips" the image against its own plane, forming an image that appears on the opposite coordinate along the THIRD axis.  

So imagine you are standing (and not rotating), surrounded by three mirrors, one infront of you, one facing your left shoulder, and third on the floor with you standing on top of it. 
1 - Front mirror arbitrarily named "XY" after the plane formed by axes named X and Y, your image is reflected against that plane and is formed along a third axis Z. 
2- The floor mirror, named XZ, will form your image along the Y axis, which means your reflection IS actually VERTICALLY reflected on the floor.
3- YZ plane - reflection along X, etc. 
Taking the second mirror which is on the floor as an example, if you flip that upside-down person so they are upright again, they will appear "horizonally" flipped. Truth is you will always be "flipped" (reflected) and that can by along any plane with reference to how you are comparing the two objects - next to each other, facing each other, or on top of each other.

Richard Feynman put it succinctly, mirrors flip depth.  They mirror depth.  Not up and down or left and right, but depth.  Depth with respect to the degree to which you observe the mirror.  It flips the first photons that hit it first, and the last photons to hit it last.

I think you could have a better explanation. The way how mirrors flip images, which depends on how the mirrors are positioned. Because we usually put mirrors vertically, and a vertical line (mirror) only blocks the light in a horizontal way, so it reflects light horizontally. The opposite way, if you put a mirror horizontally above your head, and now you need to head up to see what's in the mirror. Now a horizontal line (mirror) blocks the vertical light, and it reflects objects vertically reverse, so you will see yourself upside down. That's the reason.

Nicely done! Just adding a point to the z-axis inversion comment:

A plane occupies two axes, and a mirror can be construed to be a plane. We have a total of three spatial axes, and for a plane residing in any two of those, it should logically not be possible to discriminate between those two axes (e.g., which is 'x', and which is 'y' in this example? Does it matter - if you reverse them does the effect change?). So, the ONLY possible axis left along which mandatory inversion can take place, is the z-axis.
